title: Liberia: Unprecedented Abandonment Engulfs Logan Town - Mombo Town U.S.$1.9 M Road Project
text:
Gambia: Former Agric PS, Others Face More Charges 
In 2010, President Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf broke grounds as a demonstration of the Government of Liberia's commitment to construct the road connecting the places, but up to present, the work is yet to be completed, investigation gathers. 
Investigation deepens that even though the road is nearing completion, over the last two years no construction work has been done. Residents of the community complained that while the road is being abandoned; work already done by SEK Liberia, allegedly not durable to meet a modern road project. The road is currently in a deplorable state with several pot holes captured during the visit to the communities. Residents complain that the road also lack safety for road user as there is no sidewalk and drench to avoid flood. 
Despite most residents of the both Logan Town - Mombo Town expressed gratitude to President Johnson-Sirleaf for the road pavement project, they also expressing serious dissatisfaction over the current status of the project being superintended by the Ministry of Public Works. They are calling on the Liberian leader to provide answers to concern raised by ordering the project to re-commence. 
Elders, youth and women of the communities noted that when the road construction work started in 2012, two years after the President broke grounds in 2010, they were of the conviction that the road would have been completed soon so that it can necessitate their life betterment and economic development. 
Considering the importance of road construction in this modern age, some of the residents expressed that they thought the Logan Town Road would have help enhance linkages of relationship among the communities and businesses. 
Mr. George D. Brown, Chairman Mombo East/Stockton Creek Communities told journalists that due to poor construction work done on the road coupled with lack of sidewalk and drench system, the road users have been victim of series of motorcycles and motor vehicle accidents. 
Michael Milller, youth chairman of Mombo East/Stockton Creek Communities called on the MPW to complete their road project since in fact, SEK has abandoned the work and the MPW is the government institution responsible for all road construction in the country. 
Currently, just a stone throw from the Stockton Creek Bridge, going towards the Duala Market, using the unfinished Logan Town - Road Project, there are overused vehicles and construction equipment residents claimed have been parked for over a year. 
Martha Logan Davis, a mother of three children who sit very close to the road selling dry goods, noted that the road was abandoned by the company nearly two years ago. 
In 2010, the Government of Liberia through the Ministry of Public Works entered into a contract numbered, MPW-0084-11/12 with SEK Construction Company for the construction of a 2.5 mile-road from Logan Town to Mombo Town. 
The Ministry of Public Works entered into another contract with SEK in 2012 "for the expansion and certain additional works on the Logan Town to Mombo Town Road". The Ministry of Public Work was represented by Mr. Victor Smith who was acting Minister at the time and SEK was represented by its Chairman MamadyKomah. Liberia
